{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3274535,"name":"lichtenburg","username":"lichtenburg11235","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lichtenburg11235/{size}/179019_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-06T22:12:04.982Z","cooked":"

I made a 3D printed case that holds the Open-Mesh radio and VIVIDHOSTING radio. The new potential radio for worlds could lead to a need to swap out radios on the robot. I designed a two part case that holds both radio types. It uses 4x 10-32x1.5in bolts and 4x 10-32 nuts to hold the two parts together.
Google Drive Link

VH109 and Radio Case 12140Ã—1506 464 KB

VH109 and Radio Case 22140Ã—1506 460 KB

hello Iâ€™m looking for a cad model for the 24â€™ Champs radio, so I can design a case for it because my team (now going to worlds) has a couple needs that arenâ€™t meat by other designs and was wondering if you could post the base model just of the new radio so I would have a place to start since you are the only person I can find it under on CD as of currently.

Thanks again for the help - Jaden 2851

We created one last year when we tested the radio at one of our Off seasons. It has multiple mounting holes that should be able to work will multiple frame rail patterns. Counter bored for 10-32 Button heads (8-32 also works). Then you can easy zip-tie the radio right onto the mount.

does anyone know the weight of the old radio and what the difference is because I saw that the new radio is 0.4 lbs and was wondering what the offset is, so that teams that are on the weight limit of 125 might go over because of the radio

the weight for us after FIM states is 124.8 I think might be closer

The old radio is 0.291 lbs. But we will be fine because we do not need the radio power module and the switch which both together with the wires for that will weigh more than the difference in weight.

Iâ€™ll throw my version in the ring too. Itâ€™s pretty bullet proof, but still easy to take the lid off for taking it out. We used a similarly designed model for the old radio.

My plans are to add more mounting holes so it can be a direct mount instead of needing a plate.

I am very confused why this thread existsâ€¦ This thing does not need any additional covering. If you are worried about the zip ties not being a secure mountâ€¦ I would weigh the risk of the zip ties breaking below the risk of it overheating and throttling your bandwidth, or the risk of your 3d printed case messing with the radiation pattern.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-05-09T15:47:21.998Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":343,"readers_count":342,"score":123.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":447942,"topic_slug":"3d-printed-case-for-open-mesh-radio-and-vividhosting-radio","display_username":"Camren","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":30511,"username":"Landon_K","name":"Landon K","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/landon_k/{size}/9690_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":8}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16209,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/3d-printed-case-for-open-mesh-radio-and-vividhosting-radio/447942/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":5},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3382684,"name":"Mr. Siefen | 453","username":"kingc95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-09T16:04:59.083Z","cooked":"

I was curious what all your thumbs down were for on the other posts. This would be an interesting study for a team with time and a new radio to do. Iâ€™m curious if it does make a noticable difference in the performance of the hardware or not.

Logically it should affect the radiation pattern, but by how much and is it enough to matter? It depends on the thickness of the case, type of plastic and where the antennas are inside of the radio.

I think many teams want to have a cover for aesthetics more than protection, but if itâ€™s going to actually affect performance Iâ€™d want to know

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":17,"updated_at":"2024-05-09T16:05:52.522Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":327,"readers_count":326,"score":90.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":447942,"topic_slug":"3d-printed-case-for-open-mesh-radio-and-vividhosting-radio","display_username":"Mr. Siefen | 453","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":16209,"username":"Camren","name":"Camren","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/camren/{size}/226239_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20632,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mr. Siefen"},"post_url":"/t/3d-printed-case-for-open-mesh-radio-and-vividhosting-radio/447942/10","custom_user_title":"Mr. Siefen","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3382691,"name":"","username":"Akash_Rastogi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/akash_rastogi/{size}/169937_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-09T16:13:34.004Z","cooked":"

Personally I feel that teams using this radio in a setup not recommended by @kiettyyyy and VH should reconsider. The best practices were outlined as mounting to a metal structure and their website shows diagrams of exactly where.

Itâ€™s an FRC specific radio with explicit instructions from the manufacturer, I think teams should stick to that instead of testing on their own.

Source: https://frc-radio.vivid-hosting.net/getting-started/usage/mounting-your-radio#overview

image781Ã—663 72.3 KB

I donâ€™t think we should be celebrating designs that go directly against the manufacturerâ€™s data sheet. The thumbs down is to offset the misguided likes on those comments.

This isnâ€™t even just for a teamâ€™s performance at an event, but to alleviate the headaches that FTA, FTAA, and CSAs may encounter when a team runs into connectivity issues.

NathanZhou:

Something I am worried is these new radio do get extremely hot just running stand alone for more than 10 min. I donâ€™t know if casing it is a good idea.

This is why VH specifically states to mount to a metal surface, so as to act like a heatsink. See my post above for their notes.

Nice, simple design. Iâ€™m thinking that this would be even better if you machined it out of aluminum rather than 3d printed it. That way, the entire mount acts as a heat sink but you still get the added structure to mount securely to the frame. Itâ€™s even better than the manufacturerâ€™s idea of direct tube mounting.
